content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												What once was a very impressive little title has now turned into one of the biggest franchises for Square Enix and a Cult Favorite among the fans, so let's see how it all began shall we ?In Just Cause we play as Rico Rodriguez. He is an agent sent in to the island San Esperito. Our mission is to kill a dictator Mendoza and free the island from his reign.Back when this game came out I found it quite impressive. The Island is massive, but it doesn't matter cause there is nothing to see there. All of it is just a big jungle which all of it looks the same. There are small villages which act as outposts and you can clear them out.  The city is uninspiring and there's nothing to do there.The gameplay is by far the weakest third person shooter I have ever seen. The shooting feels clunky and sometimes my shots don't even connect with the enemies, not to mention most guns are weak as hell, and the better weapons have low ammo counts.The graphics (apart from the CGI cut scenes) are still great. The lush island is awesome and getting a boat and going through the rivers is really fun, but as stated before there's nothing to see, but it's still fun. The driving controls are some of the worst driving controls I have ever seen, they even top the driving controls in Watch Dogs. Since unlike in Just Cause 2 you can't travel with the grappling hook, so most of the time you will need to use vehicles.The game also has side quests, but most of them are boring as hell and you can grind them since they never end. So if you want something more with the game after you're done you can do the mundane side quests.The game took me 6 hours to finish, once the game is finished you can explore the island, but as stated before there's nothing to do there.The game also has a major spike in difficulty in the final missions, so be prepared to be‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•off. Overall even though the game didn't age well, it's still fun to play for a bit, but it's the weakest in the series. In the end I will give this a positive review, but I still suggest playing Just Cause 2 instead.Final Rating:6/10 - OkayIf you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review.For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

Posted: December 31, 2013
												Pros: As GTA3 clones go, adding extreme sports and OTT stunts is one of the ideas that make it worthwhile, introducing things that you find yourself wishing were in GTA3. Tremendous freedom, with multiple approaches to two thirds of the main missions(parachute in, burst through the front, sneak in, etc.). If you're in a vehicle moving fast, or you make a vertical jump of about a dozen meters or more, you can engage your parachute, from where you can comfortably shoot or grapple to any vehicle. Shooting is like a proper third person shooter, not like GTA3 and Vice City. Vehicles include cars, motorcycles, boats, helicopters and planes, all of these types can come armed with machineguns and/or rockets, and all of them useful: sail, since you're in an island paradise, and going across water may be the shortest distance between two points; helicopter flight is easily the most flexible way to travel, because of mountains and sea; and planes are by far the fastest way to travel far. Control is great, no matter what you travel by. Fairly challenging. Limits on ammo and weapon carry capacity(two pistols, two types of C4, and another two guns - choose carefully between SMGs, assault and sniper rifles, RPGs and a grenade launcher) ensure that you are careful in shootouts. A fun arcade game.Cons: Very clearly rushed, with glitches and bugs. Nothing to do once you've completed the short story and liberated all enemy zones and/or completed a certain number of the uninspired, crushingly inconsequential and repetitive side-missions. Characters are bland, and there's little to the story, meaning there's almost no "meat" to what's going on(the fun stuff is all in the game-play). Over half of the large island nation is forest and sea. Too many story missions are samey.My recommendation: If you can live with its rather rough edges, this is among the most fun open-world games.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												Get Just Cause 2 instead. It's basically the same game, except actually finished. This one only has inklings of ideas which were never developed, and simply has no polish whatsoever. For example, take the settlement takeover missions, which are a cool idea and which you'll probably be doing a lot. "Missions" might be too generous. There's basically only one (shoot enemies, destroy roadblock #1, shoot enemies, destroy roadblock #2, shoot enemies, destroy roadblock #3, rush to flag / kill a specific enemy - the only difference you can spot between them is that when taking over cities you don't have to destroy roablocks), which you will be doing over and over and over and over again. Do you at least get something cool for your troubles? Nope, just a new save point and a color of some pixels flipping on the map. Or take the combat, which you'll be doing a lot of. The game has only two levels of enemy threat. "Light drizzle" if they are using bullets, "instagib" if they're using explosives. For your own part, you'll have tiny, hard to see crosshairs (if you play at any real resolution)... or extremely intrusive autoaim which kicks in while you're manning vehicle weapons (which are another cool idea on their own) and which will actually very often prevent you from shooting what you want to shoot (say, the barricade rather than all the random soldiers all over the place). Or take the grappling hook, which is an amazingly fun tool in JC2, and which is an unreliable and unwieldy piece of crap in this game. The whole thing is just extremely rushed and upolished.Again, just get JC2 instead. I can assure you, you will not miss out on anything by skipping JC1.

Posted: December 25, 2015
												I can safely give this game the "Meh" Seal of Semi-Approval.--Just Cause is a series about blowing s$#@ up and having fun, and it all started right with this unpolished world of cross-gen mediocrity.  Yet, everything wrong with this game somehow works in its favor.  It's fairly easy to get lost in the world and start collecting things only to be interrupted by military forces, in which the surprisingly excellent gunplay grants you access to their car and a massive chase sequence that usually involves hilariously bad AI, being absolutely swarmed by enemy vehicles, and lots of stunt jumping.  The missions are solid, the voice acting is cringeworthy, and overall the game is somewhat enjoyable as a budget title.The biggest flaw, however, is its lack of polish and special mechanics.  My problem with this game is that I can't help but compare it to its legendary successor, Just Cause 2.  I know the hardware was limited and they really did make the most of Xbox/PS2 hardware, but it doesn't change the fact that after so many hours of JC2, the upgrades from game to sequel definitely hurt in trying to go back.If you have a crappy computer, want some time to kill, or just want to see where this series began, there's a fair chance you might get your moneys' worth here.  On any half-decent computer, however, I'd recommend skipping straight to its sequel.  JC2 is a damn near perfect game, and there's a reason it outshines its predecessor.

												This review is for the game ''Just Cause'',an open world third-person shooter video game,developed by the video game company Avalanche Studios.The game was published by Eidos Interactive and released in Semptember 22 on 2006(in Europe).The game can be run through Microsoft Windows,Playstation 2,Xbox and Xbox 360.The game uses the Avalanche Engine with Havok physics.Genre(s):Action-AdventureMode(s):Single-playerDistribution:Optical Disc,downloadPlotYou take control of Rico Rodriguez,an agent for an unkown organization called the Agency,who is being dropped to a tropical island(called San Esperito)by the order of the commandingofficer Tom Sheldon in order to help overthrow San Esperito's dictator,Salvador Mendoza,whom the Agency thinks to be in possession of nuclear weaponry.Soon after your arrival you rendezvouses with Tom Sheldon and his partner Maria Kane who allythemselves(as well as you) with a Guerrilla group starting a rebellion against the dictator andthe Rioja drug cartel(even though they are enemies with the government).Eventually Rico will have to facethe corrupt officials(Black Hand mercenaries)  and the Montano cartel(Rioja's drug cartel enemy).Lastly,Tom Sheldon discovers that Mendoza has in fact nuclear weapons and with San Esperito politically unstable the president is forced to retreat to his private island.He makes a last attempt to escape after he is being discovered by Rico but the agent risks his life and gets into a flying plane after a ridiculous stunt,kills the Black Hand officials and destroys the President once and for all.GameplayThe game incorporates basic third-person shooter elements in a huge driving open world environment to interact in.You are capable of walking,swimming,jumping and use a wide variety of vehicles including:cars,boats,aircrafts andmotorcycles.Rico can also perform stunds,choose when to open his parachute(of course while in air) and use the exceptionally useful Protec Grappler G3 which is a high-powered magnet harpoon device and can stick to metalsurfaces.That allows Rico to engage in a wide variety of stuntsand immobilize vehicles as well as many other things.RecapI find this game awfully boring and repetitive.Story missions are dull and uninspiring.Side missions given by the Riojadrug cartel are even worse.The graphics are exceptionally bad even for a 2006 game.And to make things worsebugs and glitches swarm about the game making it almost unplayable.Settlement liberations not challenging and alike(Kill some soldiers,destroy the roadblocks,repeat again 2 times and the capture the flag).Cliche catchphrases are pretty lame too.Q:If that's the case why bother buying or even playing the game?A:That is the video game developer's first attempt into the gaming industry.Of course there would be some mistakes.You should also take into account that it was rushed to the market for unkown reasons at least to me.Personally I played the game and completely finished it before getting to play Just Cause 2 which was released four years later.I recommend this game only if you are a completionist like me and want to explore everything that involves a gamingseries like the Just Cause series.P.S Support the developers!

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Just Cause is a cool open world game set in the fictional country of San Esperito. The story is like what you'd expect from an action movie: you play as a secret agent working to overthrow the dictatorship of Salvador Mendoza, and there's tons of explosions and stuff in the process.As far as gameplay goes, well, it's mostly fun, but there are several problems in my opinion, one of the most important ones being the driving. Driving anything in this game is pretty much impossible, as you'll soon find your vehicle going everywhere except where you want it to go. On the other hand, flying seems to be a pretty good way of getting around, as helicopters are pretty easy to use, and you can jump out of them and use a parachute to land safely. You also have a grappling hook, but using it is somewhat difficult.Besides the main story, the game also offers a few types of sidemissions, including races, side quests, and liberation missions, and there's two factions which you help during the course of the game, the Guerrila, opposed to Mendoza's government, and the Rioja Cartel, which supports the Guerrilla. Races are pretty straightforward, you only have to reach the checkpoints before the time ends; what's interesting is that you can use practically any vehicle, so if you're having difficulty with one, you can just grab a helicopter and fly around the track. Liberation missions are divided into Guerrilla missions and Rioja missions, and they consist of fighting against the government troops (in the case of the Guerrilla) or the Montano Cartel (in the case of the Rioja) in order to liberate a settlement. They all play out the same, however, with you having to kill a certain number of enemies before the next objective becomes available. As for sidequests, once again, both the Guerrilla and the Rioja offer them, but they're really repetitive, and the faction relation system is somewhat unbalanced, as it requires a lot of points, and most missions only give you 30 points.The game world is huge, with tons of towns, cities, and small villages, and plenty of jungles (maybe too many jungles) here and there. Even though there's not lots of things to see, as it gets somewhat repetitive, it's still nice to simply grab a helicopter and fly around, seeing the island below you, while the Sun sets on the horizon.The soundtrack is pretty good, adding a lot to the atmosphere during those high speed chases. As for the dialogue, well, not so much. I wouldn't say it's outright bad, but there's a few details here and there when it comes to characters speaking in Spanish.Even then, with all its flaws (including some funny glitches here and there, and a huge difficulty spike in the last story missions), I'd say Just Cause is a pretty fun game, so I can recommend it.

Posted: June 28, 2016
												This game is a buggy, unpolished, and sometimes downright boring abomination. And I love it for that.You'll get to experience a laughably primitive version of the Havok physics engine. Hell, it can't even handle a tank's turret turning without sending the tank spinning into the upper stratosphere, and other vehicles have a tendency to go flying for no apparent reason. (Looking at you, monster truck)Enemies spawn in at complete random, more often than not have I been cut off during a car chase because an enemy car materialised right in front of me. I don't know why this is a thing, but hey, more mooks to kill, amirite?Rocket launchers aren't unlocked early, I got the first one after almost 7 hours of playtime. The ammo count is pathetic and sometimes they refuse to lock onto enemies. This is a game where tanks are scary, beyond scary, actually. Because they deal a lot of damage, soak a lot of damage, and sometimes they enter hyperspace and chop your head of with a turbocharged swivel of their turret. Expect to engage in vehicular combat more than infantry vs tank combat, because your AT options will be limited at best. On the other hands, rocket-armed vehicles can decimate anything in sight in style.The story is as deranged as it gets, nothing makes any sense and I've yet to figure out what the hell is going on. On the other hand, it provides some of the silliest and most enjoyable cutscenes I've ever seen in a videogame. Expect PS1-tier facial animations. (only in cutscenes, there are no facial animations in-game)However, this game still succeeds with something, and that's providing those unscripted action-movie moments. Just as an example, here are two highlights from some of my boat shenanigans: http://plays.tv/s/Kr8ZOcCJLREWYes, it is primitive. Yes, it is buggy. Yes, it is unpolished. Yes, it is repetitive. However, if you're willing to try different things, this game allows you to create more fun for yourself. There are different ways to attack bases, you don't have to bring an attack helicopter every time, and it can be fun to get involved in a massive car chase with helis and explosions just for the hell of it.Do you want to blow things up and can come up with many ways to do it? Can you deal with wonky physics and dated gameplay? If so, this game might be something for you. I'd not pick it up outside of a sale though.

												This game won't keep you entertained for too long, but if you have any interest at all in gaming history this is probably a must-play. You can trace a lot of elements of modern games back to this particular title, both good and negative ones.On the other hand, I personally just played it because I feel a compulsive need to start with the first game of any franchise, and I think Just Cause 3 looks like a lot of fun, so 1 and 2 have to get ticked off the list.What does the game do right?- Humor so bad it's good.- Dialogue so bad it's good.- Gun play that is fairly satisfying and fun.What does the game to wrong?- Visually it's very bland. By that I mean that the graphics are as you'd expect from a 2006 title, perhaps even a little sub-par, but all throughout the game you see the same assets, the same jungle, the same tiny villages over and over again. - The gameplay is extremely repetitive, and if you're just playing this to get it off your bucket list and be able to at least claim you've done it, then there's no reason to go clear out all the outposts. When it comes to pointless sidequests and activities to keep you playing, this game makes Far Cry 4 look reasonable.I will recommend this game purely on the basis that it's two evenings of cheesy fun that can be bought for a it of loose change on sale.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
 Just Cause 1: A cause for celebration  Just Cause 1  was undoubtedly one of the best foundations for a succesful storyline, trilogy to be precise. It gave a simple development of the Agency characters which is then later advanced in future games, which was a very good judgement on The Studio's behalf. However, in JC3,  the whole concept of The Agency is abandoned, since Rico is dropped off at his supposed home nation and joins forces with the local Guerilla fighters, but we will talk about his nationality later on.  The Gang System I really did enjoy the gang aspect of the Just Cause Franchise, JC2 had a good selection, but  it was only limited to gangs vs government rather than the Gang vs Gang aspect, which was unfortunately missed out and undeveloped - Razak says that "If you cross me, I will kill you" or something like that, surely if you were driving a Roaches car into the Ular Boys Stronghold, it would say "Your cover was blown", geez, I should have written more in the JC2 review now that I think about it...  I loved the fact that in JC1, conflicting Gangs like the Riojas and The Montanos would start to fight in the streets because they saw each other, but the uncalledfor attacks by the other gangs when you are driving a school bus at 30mph are not really helpful... The AI The Gang AI is quite clever, they kind of adapt to your actions, but nothing like MGSV:TPP, when they overdo that AI aspect slightly too much. The Government forces are quite odd because you can hear them shouting  "Stop right there, Citizen!"  when, yet again, you are going 30mph in a school bus! In effect, the AI could have been more well done.  The graphics Since this is a Just Cause title, you would expect the graphics to outperform any other competing game in the market at that time. And so it did. The graphics were absolutely insane - the sunsets can be absolutely phenomenal and the sea, oh wow! Summing up, JC titles will always grab that no.1 spot for "the insane graphics award". The physics This is where JC1 kind of fell down. The driving did not feel as realistic as it should be, but that mistake was rectified in JC2. The grapple gun was a weak invention, but deep down, the main motif in the JC saga is the evolution of the grappling device, and that is supposed to sybolise some deep s**t. The soundtrack The best part of JC1 is, by far, the soundtrack. I always loved, and still love, listening to the Hispanic Music everytime you completed a mission, however, the music does get a little excessive when you get in a helicopter and, this is an XBOX 360 example, press RT on the controller, suddenly some inspiring music starts to play and you end up crashign down to the ground because it caught you off guard. Yep, That's JC1 for you. But in JC2, that mistake was rectified  so that the music doesn't bombard you every second, actually, it is quite a rarity to encounter music during a playthrough, it only happens when you float through the air with your parachute deployed for 10 minutes or so.  To conclude for this section, I would say that the soundtrack was well composed, but the timing could have been an improvement. The messup. --This whole section is about the storyline of JC and its routes, if you do not wish to read this, please disregard and head straight to conclusions--  (It is marked as a spoiler) So as you may recall, I spoke about Rico Rodriguez's identity in one of the previous sections - I say that "he is dropped off at his  HOME COUNTRY  - which is supposed to be Medici, surely - it is NOT Medici! It was stated that apparently, Rico is from San Espirito, but that is entirely debatable since JC is not know to be a "Story Rich" franchise. Maybe the producers decided to rename San Espirito and make it better, which explains the Provincial settings which requires a liberation aspect, which has been omnipresent since JC1. I'm not sure if it is stated in JC2's PDA information for Rico, but I am pretty sure it says that his birthplace is San Espirito, or maybe it says -unknown-. But really, to make a whole new Hispanic or Italian island defeats the purpose of the real place -  SAN ESPIRITO .  Conclusions From my experiences with this game, I can say that it is really enjoyable and is a great introduction to the JC franchise, but really, buying JC3 due to the graphical upgrade really undermines the real purpose of the Grapple Hook evolution theory shown in the franchise, as modern players will seek out a pretty game - they will never share the experience that you will have when people ask you, remember that mission when you  Burnt an entire weed field?  - that person who bought JC3 will say, what mission, I only liberate provinces in JC3. You look at them and say, wow, this is the true definition of an idiot. Trust me, it feels so good when you find an idiot like that IRL (Shoutout to my 'end franchise joiners' out there!)Thank you all for reading this mini essay - enjoy your time on JC1!

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Inspired by free-roaming action games such as Grand Theft Auto and Far Cry, Just Cause drops you (literally, out of an aeroplane) onto a tropical island that's in need of a little regime change.With silent backing from the CIA, your character Rico has gadgets, guns and an endless supply of disposable vehicles with which to wreak havoc.Rico also has the infinite use of a parachute that pops out and packs itself away in the blink of an eye. All you need do is find a lofty point from which to leap and you can drift over villages, motorways and wide channels of water.Fire your grappling gun and Rico will hook onto passing cars or helicopters for a little paragliding - handy when you need an altitude advantage over your opponents or want to catch up on a crook.However, even with this unique mode of transport, getting around is a slow and sometimes tedious affair. Reaching each new mission marker can sometimes mean at least five minutes of travel time.As with GTA, the action here involves hectic car chases, shootouts with the corrupt local officials and various seek-and-destroy missions in which you can enjoy the spectacle of big things blowing up. Typically, the player can hijack cars, bikes, boats and even helicopters, as well as kill time on various side missions that involve collecting hidden packages or performing hitman duties.Sloppy vehicle handling, some bugs in the design of the missions and the endless travel means it doesn't hit the same high notes as GTA and others, but the mindless action is still good dumb fun. An ambitious action affair that sometimes gets a little lost in the wilderness.

												I enjoyed Just Cause 2 enough that I decided to go back and play the first one. After finishing it I'd have to say that if you've played the second one, you're better off not touching the first installment. That's not to say that Just caise is a a bad game. It's still a pretty cool open world game with nice gunplay and the jungle setting I enjoy. It's also easy to go from story mission to story mission without all the chaos nonsense of part 2. The stories between 1 and 2 are pretty much the same thing. You're off to an island to liberate it blah blah blah so nothing to see here. Controls were nice and easy (although the grappling hook from Just Cause 2 was sorely missed here) and the missions aren't terribly dificult, other than two that made me want to pull my hair out (a special "screw you" for the designer of mission 17 I think it was).  If you haven't played Just Cause 2, this is a cool introdcution to the series but you're better off just sticking with part 2. It just does everything better and you don't need to have played this part to get JC2. This shouldn't be a surprise but hey, I'll just save you eight hours. Still this game gets a 7/10 from me.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I really want to recommend this game, but there are more negatives than positive. Almost everything has a problem with it.Just Cause is the first game in the Just Cause series, made by Eidos Studios. After a few years, Square Enix took the developing rights of JC and made Just Cause 2, a HUGE improvement to the first one.Let's start off with the graphics. They O.K for 2006, but it could've definetely been improved. Rico Rodriguez, the game's main protagionist, has the most bland outfit ever. (All black. Is he Goth or something?) The cutscenes look WAY better than the actual game, but seeing what exactly the cutscenes look, I'd stick with the normal graphics. Another thing that threw me off is that they have 1280 x 600 and 1600 x 1200, but no 1366 x 768. Why not? Surely there would've been 1336 x 768 back then. Not a big problem, but a little annoying.Next, the story. Basic. You are Rico Rodriguez, Agency agent. You must fight the evil forces of the president of San Esperito, Salvador Mendoza by blowing up stuff, helping a guerilla army fight the corrupt police and helping Yellow drug cartel fight Purple drug cartel. That's kinda it. Or that's all I know, for now. I haven't finished the game yet, nor do I have any intention of. This is more simple than your regular oh-no-guy-killed-family-must-kill-all-living-things movie. Like I said, I haven't finished the game yet, but I wished the story had more depth. More complexity.The combat. Oh sweet Jesus. Where to start? If you hit a car, member, or other vehicle of the police or Purple drug cartel, THEY WILL BE UP YOUR‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• They will send loads of cars and trucks and helicopters after you. It's fun, until you get out of your flaming car and either get killed by the explosion or the flurry of bullets. If you DO happen to survive, you can shoot 'em. But, you might be outnumbered. There are a lot of weapons, and utilizing them is your #1 priority. The problem is, when you die, you lose ALL your weapons, except for your (crappy) grappling hook and your dual pistols, which conviently have infinite ammo. And your safehouses, the places you spawn at, have certain weapons. For example, one safe house has a bazooka and shotgun, but another one has a machine gun and a pistol. So if you want a big arsenal, you're gonna cross the whole map building it up, only to die to that stray missile from that Apache.And now, the enemies. There are the police, who fight the guerillas occasionaly and mostly lose. Sometimes, if you're lucky, you might see a guerilla helicopter shoot at a police car or van and explode in a unimpressive explosion. There are also liberations, which involves storming a town with other guerilla soldiers while fighting police and SWAT and a po-po heli. There are also roadblocks, depending on the size of the town. Little ones, roadblocks. Big ones, a swarm of army soldiers. Also fighting with you is the Yellow drug cartel, who is fighting Purple drug cartel. There are also liberations here, but you're fighting Purple drug cartel instead of police. The missions are as hard as hell sometimes, like one where you have to destroy coca fields. When I completed that objective and went to a bar to complete it, I was running away on some baggage carrier modified to spray chemicals while Purple drug cartel and police are shooting me from every direction. About 400 meters from my destination, I had to leg it, chased by numerous Purple drug cartel and police bikes and vans and a helicopter. I reached the bar just in time, when I only had a little line of health.CONCLUSION: This game definetly has its good features, like adrenaline-pumped moments and blowing up stuff, but it is light, compared to the bad features. This game felt like it was an idea, not completed or polished. I definitely recommend the second JC, which is an actual game instead of an experiment like this game.FINAL SCORE: 4/10

Just Cause is very immersible, frustratingly challenging, ahead of its time, and a downright wonderful video game.Aside from some ridiculous glitches, lack of deep utilization of certain characters, and especially particular unfair situations, I continued enjoying the game within the span of the story progressing. Throughout my experience, I remained totally stoked and wowed by the depth of colorful landscapes that pertained the fictionalized tropical setting. As an open-world game, you're given many advantages to tackle your missions creatively along with hidden bonuses to allow further replay value.Though this game wasn't intended to be perfect, or even garner a broad audience without alienating a few, the best judgment will come if you set aside your worries and become the ultimate vigilante in what would begin the legacy of the Just Cause  franchise!

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Just Cause? Just pass. You're honestly better skipping this title and moving onto Just Cause 2, you won't miss anything. Just Cause 1 has a slew of problems, not limited to: poor controls especially when using the grapple/parachute mechanics, vehicle handling is clearly designed with controllers in mind, most notably when using the auto-aiming mounted turrets, a ridiculous clich√© story including drug cartels, Nazi scientists and a whole lot of rockets, and finally it crashes alot. In my 8 hour playtime alone, I crashed six times, three of which where on the same mission, I've Got the Power [#13]. The only real positives I can think about are the graphics are moderately good, ignoring noticable copy-paste jobs on buildings and in jungle, the soundtrack is perfect for the game, and some of the missions including, Some Enchanting Evening [#15],  Dismissed Without Honors [#17] and the last two thirds of Taking Out the Garbage [#19b-c]. If you're going to play this regardless, then I recommend running through the story and leaving a majority of the optional content. The game is only 19 missions long with the last mission split into 3 parts. In summary, I'd still recommend skipping this and playing the second game in the series as it has improved the core idea/gameplay of JC1 into a more complete and enjoyable game.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												Being the first game in the Just Cause series, you shouldn't expect it to be perfect, because it's not. But for all it's flaws, it's glorious because of how massive in scope and epicness it is.Something like ~365 sq miles, the world is your playground, and not because of the sidequests, which are many yet repetitive; i.e; help the guerillas take over political territory, and help the Rioja family expand and defeat the other competing/mafia type family. The side quests are many and they do have their advantages when advancing through the game for opening safe houses and extra weapons, but are otherwise unnecessary.No, the world is your playground because of how ridiculous it is. Police everywhere, villages are spread out, mountains, mountains, and mountains are all over with hills, rivers, cliffs, etc. The only thing that kept the diverse landscape vague was the color, which is pretty much all green. There's grass everywhere, you can't go anywhere without seeing grass unless you drive a boat out to sea. A game released in 2006, this could have easily been on all next gen systems, but you can tell Avalanche had focused with the Xbox and PC while also trying to transition to 360, as the models are pretty good, but the textures are certainly at the end of the Xbox and PS2 era.As for travel, you get planes, helicopters, tanks, cars, trucks, etc. There's an infinite amount of vehicles at your disposal. Again, you'll have to advance the sidequests to unlock some of the cool ones, but completely unnecessary.The plot is okay. It's nothing special, run and gun doing espionage esq type missions, sort of like James Bond espionage, but less stealthy. You are Rico and are sent by the Agency to help rid the country island of San Esperito of its corrupt El Presidente and followers. It's fun, but rather short, you can probably beat it in 4 or 5 hours, depending on the difficulty and amount of time you spend in between missions.8.3/10

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Just Cause is a slightly older game (around the end of the PS2's life cycle) that boasts a massive area to explore, a seemingly endless amounts of side missions and content to take on, and much much more. I recently picked up the series on sale, and as per usual, I'm writing this review from a completionist perspective. I've done all there is to do in the game and am trying to judge it based on all that it has to offer.Now before I get blasted by hate (becaus a LOT of people like this game, and may get butt hurt because of the not recommended review I'm giving) hear me out. I will give credit where credit is due and review the game as fairly as I possibly can.PROS:-The game does NOT look ten years old unless you look at the characters. The environment is beautiful, the water physics are perfect, and all in all it just looked good.-MASSIVE area. They didn't lie here, the area is so large that it would take literal days to explore it all. There are tons of easter eggs hidden away, like a hidden temple that is unmarked, to explore that reward you for making the effort.-Some aspects of the gameplay were really satisfying, I like the concepts of taking over the islands of San Esperito one area at a time, it makes you feel like you're actually fighting a war and need to think tactically. It also gives the game a great flow for progression.-Instead of a levelling system, you have to rise through the ranks of the Guerilla faction, and the Rioja drug cartel to get better gear. This is a really cool concept for incentives, as it makes you want to do more for these factions.Now you may be thinking "Whoa, Pokemon_Master503, this sounds awesome! Why could you possibly call this game a pile of steaming crap?" Well...CONS:-SEVERELY underwhelming story. This game has around 21 missions (or 19, if you count the last one, which is one continuous mission segmented into three different chapters as three missions) The story missions aren't that difficult, and could honestly be beaten in their  entirety in about three or four hours. "But you have 37 hours logged!" I hear you say. Remember, I'm writing a completionist review of the game, therefore the rest of that time is made up of other content. -Cardboard characters and lackluster storytelling. The game doesn't make you care at all about the people's plight in San Esperito, the characters, the Agency, your partners, or the resistence. These elements take a backburner to the filler content that was packed into the game. For a single player only game, you would think story and good characters would be a must, but here they clearly weren't important at all. Which brings us to our next point.-Copy and pasted side missions. The game has 9 races, 13 collectathon missions, settlement overthrowing, and side missions for the guerilla and Rioja factions. The first two classes of missions were all unique and each individual race and mission was treated as an individual part of the game, but the last two, which are meant to help you out in the story because of the unlocks, were simply carbon copies of each other. Settlements all looked nearly EXACTLY the same, with either coastal town, rural town, city, or military base as their type. These four are distinguishable from each other, but not distinguishable within each type. For the Rioja settlements, save for a handful, they are all the exact same more or less.  For side missions, they are algorithmically generated, so the side missions aren't actually rewarding or change the world around you, like side missions SHOULD. they just advance your rank in the respective faction, but it gets worse, where they are algorithmically generated, they repeat the same missions over and over again. 200+ side questss? More like 5 of the same with varying location. On that note-Copy and pasted environment, The environment doesn't change at all. Sure, it's algorithmically generated and huge, but THERE'S NOTHING THERE.-And last but not least GLITCHES. GOD THE GLITCHES. "gets off motorbike, motorbike goes flying across map." "'Tank just casually flying for no reason." "Spawning in a place where you can't move" IT'S SO FUN.If you're GONNA buy, buy it on sale. like for $3 or below

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I mainly played this, just to see how Just Cause 2 got it's roots. I can see that the roots for Just Cause 2 were well fertilized, because Just Cause OG is sh**!Well, okay, to be fair Just Cause 1 is a lot better than a lot of other games. It feels sort of like playing Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas, with slightly less clunkier controls and slightly better graphics. However, the game has some severe problems with both narrative and gameplay that cause it to just truly suffer.My biggest qualms with the gameplay is how easily cheated it can be. The loading screens advertize all the cool weapons and vehicles you could unlock by freeing more cities, but I got pretty much all the best gear by the end only by playing the regular story missions. And the two staples of the game- the parachute and grappling hook- both absolutely suck in this game. For one, the grappling hook is very selective. It will latch onto any vehicle or person you aim it at, but not trees, rocks, or land- which renders it basically pointless. Plus, parachuting to cars or helicopters is rubbish, since you have to reel yourself close enough to the vehicle for it to work. And Scorpio obviously has some sort of strange disease in his arms, causing them to only aim his grappling hook forward. Once a helicopter flies behind you while you reel it in, you're done. And trying to get onto cars is a massive pain, since you gradually sink to the ground (even if the car is driving at top speed).The gameplay also takes its biggest dip during the end mission. The game builds up all this variety and open mission play-style, and the end mission completely negates that. You fly in on a helicopter but can't fly it to the island. Cars attract helicopter missiles. And missiles blasting your body cause you to bounce back and forth like a pinball, constantly taking damage. And damage can only be healed by the random health-pack spawning out of dead enemies, which is very uncommon.The cutscenes are also really weird to watch. The animation studio chose some very strange character models (and some even worse voice actors), and the scenes that explain situations come off as weird, in the sense that characters say sentences in completely off tones, or come off as weird since the characters themselve look very inhuman. In fact, Just Cause has a very toy-ish feel. The cars look like Hot Wheels cars, the characters look and animate like action figures. Even the samey world of San Esperito has a kid's-jungle-themed-toy-box appeal. The game just doesn't have a very fun or realistic draw to it.I'm not saying everyone would hate this game. Between the wide variety of story missions, vast content, and world to explore- plenty of gamers will enjoy the original Just Cause. It just didn't impress me. I'm very picky with my sandbox games, and if you other 5% of Steam users that agree with my opinions are reading this, then you can be assured that Just Cause is not the game for you.

												If you love Just Cause 2 then you have to play the original. Whilst JC2 is all about causing as much chaos as possible, JC1 is all about the story and the missons. The game still features a massive map in which you are free to do as you wish, and also includes lots of cars, aircraft, boats etc. Whilst you aren't exploring the massive island, you'll be liberating towns from the government, doing side missions such as assisnating key government figres, or even simple things like collecting cars or drug deals. JC1 feels a lot like earlier Grand Theft Auto games, You have a safehouse where you can store weapons and cars etc. And whilst this game does feature a paracehute, and a grapple gun, yes a gun, you have to equip it to use it. You shouldn't count on it to get you around. Overall the game is very enjoyable, despite showing its age in the graphics department the fun still remains. So, if you enjoy Just Cause 2 and maybe you are interested in seeing where JC2 came from, Maybe you want to go back for the story, Or maybe you ae just looking for another game to add to your Steam Libary, I would absoloutely recommend this. Even better if you can get it in a steam sale ;)

Posted: January 14, 2013
												An "Okay" game. Does not port well though. The controls don't support anything but keyboard/mouse, and the game suffers for it. The driving controls very much need analog control, and using WASD makes driving near impossible at high speed, or when attempting precision. You'll get frustrated with the seemingly random deaths, and the checkpoint system can actually hurt you. For instance, you can run into a mission, and spawn a gigantic army. When you die and respawn/reload, that gigantic army is still there. So trying and failing a mission a couple times can ruin your run. You have to reload the entire game, or go do other tasks. Stil looks pretty though, given its age.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												I bought this game to tide myself over until I could muster enough money to buy a machine that could run Just Cause 2 at any decent frame rate, and I definitely can't say I regret my purchase.For a 2006 title it has a huge sandbox. Even some recent  titles struggle to compare- it is visually stunning; the  screenshots on the store page don't do it justice, on higher graphical settings it feels like you're on holiday, the most danderous holiday you'll have. Although saying that, there is very little variation from mountainous forest to tropical beach,and the cities are not quite GTA V's los santos. The in game music is very nice, I could listen for hours. It captures the Caribbean setting perfectly, in my opinion.It never won't be fun to fly a plane close enough to the ground to see  the foliage and then hastily disembarking to watch the carnage unfold, and this game, for it's time, gives a decent variety of planes, helicopters, cars, boats, guns, and explosives to play with. The downside being, of course, that many such toys are locked away untill you've completed dismayingly similar missions numerous times. Which may have been more interesting for much longer had the hostile NPCs been given any form of a competent AI, and the friendly AI seems to be all too intrigued about what's coming out the end of your gun, though I shouldnt complain about AI from that era. Also I can't tell if any of the guns do more or less damage. A stats screen wouldnt have gone amiss, if the different gun shapes aren't purely for aesthetics. As a result the side missions are an absolute chore and still necessary to get anything large and flammable. From the little Just Cause 2 I've been able to play, the grapple hook and parachute system is much more fluid, but don't get me wrong, the system in the original works fine. The animations in the game such as Rico's running looks pretty dodgy and can be pretty amusing at first, but is distracting from there on out. The story isn't brilliant, but who's playing games of this genre in place of a bedtime read? The greatest annoyance I have with this game are the NPC voices; the developers seemed content to hire just two voice actors for the entire civilan population, though, it's nothing a low flying plane can't fix.All in all, Just Cause is definitely worth your time, whether you dont yet have the computing power to run Just Cause 2, just enjoy the genre because this is a great game in it's own right, or have already completed the Just Cause 2 and want to experience it's roots, and for under ¬£5 is a bargain. If you can get it on sale, all the better. however if it's between Just Cause and it's sequal, Just Cause 2 would be a better use of your cash.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												While the second game is obviously superior, there are a few things that the first does better.- Everything from the shooting to the flying is faster and more responsive, if a bit unrealistic. For example, stunt jumps aren't necessarily affected by gravity, planes never stall, and helicopter propellor blades can touch almost anything without affecting control.- The entire game can be taken at one's own pace, with side missions free to perform at the player's choosing.- The world has one central theme, Caribbean jungle, as opposed to every type of biome crammed into one country. This makes the locations memorable by relying on clever geography and buidling placement, instead of the false illusion of a major change of global locale. Plus, it's just pretty to look at, most of the time.That being said, the game isn't perfect. There are plenty of bugs to look out for, both fun and bad. I've gotten trapped inside garages simply by respawning. I've driven a motorcycle so fast that I crashed into a person's house and became stuck inside. All of those incidents required me to load a previous save. Then there are the police who never EVER shut up, and the idiotic AI that deems it fit to pilot a helicopter into the side of a mountain or skyscraper. There's a monster truck with hollow tires. There are also the occasional missing or misapplied textures.Yet, on the other hand, I come back and find new bugs, or perhaps just oversights, every time I play. Rico is capable or rocket-jumping with the correct equipment, something I never thought I would see outside of FPS. He can kill himself with a heavy drop. Hell, once I took down a passing helicopter simply by requesting a vehicle at the right time. I've toyed around with the camera by grappling onto boats outside of the game's invisible ocean walls. It's even possible to do some sweet tricks by letting the cannon on a tank touch an immovable object. It's not often I see a big vehicle like that spinning and flipping that quickly.All in all, it's a good sandbox game, but don't expect a lot of depth.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												It's like Grand Theft Auto but on an Island, with a grappling gun, and can eject yourself from moving vehicles and skydive and use a parachute. There's also a lot of trees.Enemies appear out of nowhere and disappear in front of your eyes on occasions. You can steal a car and have the whole islands army on your‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•with no stars to indicate when the assault on you will ever end. (It won't). They will gun you down to the end of the earth or until you reach your objective and then it's mission complete.Cars stick to you when they are chasing and ramming you, can be a pain to shake off and driving uphill is a struggle.But then, when you can climb out of your vehicle and jump in to another. Who cares about the bad things. I drive my pickup and then climb out on to the roof and jump in to a sports car alongside me. Then I race to the edge of a cliff and surf on roof, leaping from it just as it goes over the edge. Free falling for a moment and then releasing my parachute, I float down to the sea, hop in a boat and speed off to another island, and on my way, spot a plane that takes my fancy. Very short game if you only do the main missions, which is what I did. There are side missions which are like Assassins Creed or Far Cry where you take over the area by destroying blockades with your team of rebels and then eventually once enough damage has been made change the flag in the town centre. I didn't really care for these as they are very repetitive.A nice feature which helped to navigate the map easier and a lot quicker was the extraction option that is in the PDA menu, which can be used at any time (even whilst on a mission) as long as you are not under attack. Where a helicopter will pick you up and take you where ever you want to go, be it to a new mission briefing or just to one of your safe houses. You can also have vehicles dropped off to you using heavy drop from the PDA.Kind of hard to say if I should recommend this or not.It has some very good positives and being an open world game has the ability to bring a lot of hours of game time just roaming the island and getting up to mischief. However there isn't a massive amount of vehicles and all of the terrain is pretty much the same (lots of dirt roads, few tarmac ones, trees. mountains) and not much going on the street in general unless the army are after you (which is kind of all the time) The game is a bit of a bad port from (what I've read) the XBOX (not 360)/PS2 version of the game. When in the menu there is no mouse cursor to select options and navigating must be done from the directional buttons on keyboard and return and No controller support (although I didn't try). The games display aspect ratio is 4:3 at 1024x768 with no support for widescreen monitors by default. (To allow the use of 1920x1080 16:9 you need can get a universal resolution changer file from WideScreen Gaming Forum which is easy enough to add to the games install directory in order to change this - http://www.wsgf.org/dr/just-cause) Although this does stretch the HUD, PDA and map screens noticeably and the cut scenes more so.I played at 5760x1080 res using this fix and in game the resolution was fine. If you see this game on sale grab it. I got Just Cause and Just Cause 2 with DLC for ¬£3.24 in the sales. For that price I would recommend this game all day. Even if it has got a few flaws, its still a fine game with around 21 missions, lots more side missions and being an open world game is more what you make of it when not doing these. 69/100

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												TL;DR? Pros: Big world, Fun gameplay, Exciting Music, Badass charactersCons: Too easy, Too short (6 hours), 'Meh' driving, A bit repetitive'Wow!' was my initial reaction to playing this game. This game is really good in my opinion, but not amazing. It is too easy unfortunately but you can easily get past that with the bada$$ story and fun gameplay. The driving isn't particularly great but it is still much better than Just Cause 3, which had some of the stiffest driving in a modern openworld game. Music is excellent too. Graphics wise, I got no complaints, this game is aging but it still looks decent. The map is actually rather big but not cramped with things to do. It is REALLY short! It is about 6 hours, but on a sale (of which I bought with ¬£1.24) I can safely say it is worth it. However, do not expect very much content if you buy this game for ¬£7. There is also a feeling of repetitiveness in the game which is certainly not amazing, however in short bursts (1 hour a day) you can have as much fun as you damn well want. Storywise there isn't much to say really, and I won't spoil anything huge. The story is basically you are assigned to kill a president (like you do in every Just Cause game). Even though that idea might sound a bit boring on paper, the quest is thankfully filled with cool characters.I played this game first on PS2 for 10 minutes and never played again because of its lackluster technicality, so I can safely say that this game is recommended on PC other than on anything else. Overall I give it a 7/10 but I definitely recommend it on a sale!

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												I rate the game Just Cause 4/5. Overall this is a Good game. It is a fun but flawed, third-person perspective, grand-theft-auto style, open-world adventure game. It has aged relatively well for a 10 year old game.Incredibly ambitious but terribly flawed, this game is still quite a bit of fun to play and features some very pretty tropical landscapes which shine through despite what are, by today's standards, generally mediocre and somewhat buggy graphics. For the current price of 7 dollars or so, this game gives you a lot of fun for your money. +Good graphics which adequately depicted the heat and humidity of the game's tropical setting. The colors used by this game were bright, hot and at times, even muggy but consistently beautiful. The graphics were always very cartoony however but perfectly matched the game's silly sense of humor and ludicrous stunts and physics.+This game gives you tremendous freedom and the landmass of the area you get to explore is truly humongous. No spatial compression here (like in Skyrim where the place looks larger than it actually is), unlike in Skyrim, this game really is as huge as it looks and you will usually need a helicopter or airplane to get around from place to place in a timely fashion (which gives you the most beautiful views of the game anyhow). Unfortunately, there isn't much to do in the big environments you have available to you.+Trying out all the vehicles and zipping all over the island and off of cliffs is a LOT of fun. Finally getting into a helicopter and flying around is even more fun especially since the game becomes even more beautiful at that altitude (fewer visual bugs caught my eye at high altitudes). The vehicle stunts were fun (but the grappling hook gun thing was always cumbersome). This game has great controls and makes it easy to reconfigure those controls to suit your personal taste once you figure out how the control menu works (and that its perfectly ok to have key conflicts).+/-Severely buggy. Physics bugs are particularly prevalent. Doors of cars fly off and into the distance at tremendous velocities when you open them. Traversing a turret on an armored car causes the car somersault crazily up into the air. Rotor blades ignore tree branches as if they aren't even there. The physics engine isn't remotely realistic and in many ways seems more similar to the physics in loony tunes or something than to real life. Rather than causing frustration however the bad physics leads to a lot of laughter and unexpected funny moments wherein stuff that should not possibly happen, happened. Mostly (except for the problem with traversing turrets) the physics problems actually make this already easy game even easier.+/-This is a very easy game and there are few missions which will prove challenging. Unfortunately the final mission is much, much harder than the rest of the game (I had to try if about 7 times or more before I got through it). For the most part though the game will seem too easy rather than too hard.+/- Merely adequate sound effects and mediocre (at best) music which quickly becomes repetitive given the potential length of the game. The voice acting is good (your character looks and sounds like Antonio Banderas, but he repeats his little taunts too often. Enemy taunts and voices are repeated too often also. There is no GTA style fake radio and you cannot apparently insert your own music into this game making for a very boring soundscape throughout. This meant I turned the volume down pretty far most of the time making this a very quiet game for me to play. The sound effects aren't that great when turned up far anyhow.+/- The game's main plot/story isn't totally boring but it's not nearly as interesting as it could have been. The major problem is that none of the characters explained in any great detail nor is the overall situation. Maybe there's more background information in an instruction manual somewhere which I didn't bother to read.-The side missions are generally repetitive and boring. The best thing about them is that they are entirely optional. You don't have to do them at all in order to play the game and the rewards they yield don't hardly make them worth the effort of doing them anyhow.-The enemy AI is about as good as it was in GTA III. That's not so good, which makes the game even easier. Enemy soldiers run around fighting for themselves with no squad-based tactics like a senseless mob. This helps make battles feel chaotic (because this way they actually are) but they don't feel remotely real.-You can explore but the HUGE tropical island environments are ultimately mostly uniform and boring and not very interactive. The civilian population is not very interactive either. You can hit them with cars or not or whatever but it makes no difference. You can't have sex with them or anything like that (like in GTA III). There's no sense of morality and no consequences for wantonly killing bystanders. There's no multiple ending structure to this game either. The island population is just there as random bystanders and to provide you with ample vehicles to hijack. Asides from tooling around in various vehicles and doing repetitive side missions or the games relatively few main-plot missions there just isn't much to do given the truly massive amount of geographic territory the game gives you access to. This is Just Cause's biggest, most critical flaw.-Given how remote many of the locations in the game look the tropical nation's dirt and non-dirt roads alike are all too packed with traffic. There is almost an inner-city level traffic almost everywhere you go no matter how deep in the countryside you are which always seemed really weird.

Posted: November 8, 2015
												5/10. This game is the first in the just cause series and it is not hard to notice. The open world adventure doesn't miss with airplane jacking or helicopter stealing using a grappling hook to reel yourself in. Though fun, the tight controls and awkward camera angle, when an air vehicle flies by, makes it difficult.             The problem I had with this game is the many many glitches and high difficulty spike,early-mid game. The enemy helicoptors will gun you down without hesitation immediatly, whether you see them or not. Even while parachuting I found that the enemy is more accurate at hitting me when im in the air, than when i stand still. It gets even more fustrating when you finally steal a chopper from the AI, only for it to be immediatly crashed, as the chopper accelerates the opposite direction when you latch on, or having it shot down by the enemies Anti Air. Another time I spawned in a garage where there is no exit, therefore, I had to load my last saved game. The resolution options are garbage, I had to go and customize the settings in order for the game to fit my screen, but it causes the game to not respond when minimized.           Other annoyances are the constant and repetitive AI speech "stop right there citizen!" as your freely roaming around. The driving mechanics seem as though your driving on ice. The auto aim in vehicles does not let you choose your target, unless you move the camera to the edge of the screen and it auto locking onto whomever is in the middle.            The side missions and pick up collectibles felt useless as it only builds your rank within a faction. The resaon it seemed so pointless is because 3/4 of the unlocks are weapons the enemies drop, while at the final stages of the rank is when you unlock the chopper, or rocket launcher. By that time I hadnt needed the extras, since I was already done with the story. It would have been better to preview the weapons before, to have fun with..before the unlock through the faction.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This game created a massive challenge for me in scoring it, and deciding on wether or not I should reccomend it. On its own merits, it provides large amounts of fun and entertainment, at least for a while. The issue is, however, that there are better alternatives. Look, this review will 100% grade it on it's own, however, I am under the belief that if there's a better alternative, why get the lesser?StoryThis game has a typical Just Cause-esque action story, where you bring down an evil dictator ruling over a strong island. What I find unique is the inclusion of drug cartels, and being able to rank up with them and rebels in order to get better weapons. You play as Rico Rodriguez, a dictator removal specialist, and go through many missions in order to eventually remove the dictator.GameplayI actually haven't finished the game yet, but I have almost 10 hours of gameplay, so I can speak relatively well in this department. First, the cartels are essentially a carbon copy of the police and rebels, so there isn't too much interest there, aside from a little variation in missions. To gain their trust, you capture settlements owned by the purple cartel, or government. While it's fine at first, it's extermely repetitive, as it works the exact same every single time, with absolutely no variation aside from difficulty and weaponry, and perhaps the setting. The missions are fairly interesting, if not a little dull, but can provide some entertainment. Causing mayhem in this game is possible, with stealing cars, exploding police, etc, but can get a bit dull after a while, without enough variation. Exploration of the island would be great, as there are a few landmarks and interesting locations, but it's mostly boring and all the same, jungles and small towns. Gameplay is somewhat repetitive, but still engaging, at least for a while, or short intervals.Vehicles are usually fine to use, but controls, particularly in chases and turns, are atrocious. They are usuable and fine, but sharp turns can lead to the most ridiculous swaying, and a mission failure. It's fun at times, but often annoying.The Heavy Drop system of this game is very limited, in that it only has 4 available vehicles, but they are helpful and pretty cool in their own right.Navigation is alright, but a little wary and bothersome at times. Heavy Drops and being able to be sent to bases help, though.CombatGunplay is terrible, and incredibly ridiculous, and yet pretty fun. It can be incredibly annoying at times, though. Some vehicles also have weapons, and usually they are pretty powerful, and tons of fun to use.StyleYeah, big suprise, the graphics aren't great, but it's not terrible. It looks pretty fine, and never gets too distracting, unless your used to gorgeous looking games. The entire island, though, looks like a massive jungle with a few towns and cities, so there isn't much to see, and it kind of blends altogether.Music and Sound(I've decided to seperate this from Style)The game sounds really good, and the music is gorgeous. It really gives a good feeling, and fits in perfectly. It sounsd great. The sound effects work well, they sound exactly as they are and have fairly good quality. Dialoge is a little iffy, but it works alright. The only issue is when a random cop yells "Stop, Citizen!" over and over, it happens surprisingly a lot.CharactersThe characters are fairly generic and forgettable, with a few exceptions. Sheldon seems fairly interesting, with his generally secrative nature.Final VerdictJust Cause isn't a bad game by any means, but it's not perfect. It's a lot of fun to play, and enjoyable, however, there is a far surperior alternatives. Just Cause 2, for about 7 more dollars, provides much more gameplay and entertainment, and a much more polished game. For some more, buy Just Cause 3. It's a perfection of the idea, and delivers thousands of hours of potential gameplay. I would actually get the Just Cause Pack, selling both Just Cause 1 and Just Cause 2, on sale. You could grab it for about 2-5 bucks, and get 2 pretty fun games. If it isn't on sale, however, I can't recommend it. It isn't a bad game by any means, just too mediocre for the price and considering alternatives. I may change it to a reccomendation if the price for JC2/JC3 raises, or if Just Cause's price gets reduced to maximum 5 dollars. Just Cause gets a 6/10, grab it with Just Cause 2 on sale, or just get JC2/JC3 and skip it.FOOTNOTE: Guys, there is a difference between disagreeing with a review, and it being an actual terrible review. By no means do you have to agree with everything I said, but I was as real as I could be in it, not just giving 1 sentence of "it crshed for me!".

Posted: December 3, 2015
												Because whatever why not is a fantastic gaming concept executed very wrong, the game features a sandbox world where you take on missions to overthrow the local goverment and side missions to help the rebels take over city districts while combining cool stunts to vehicle exploration, but this game just doesnt pull off the sandbox world like jak 2/3 and gta of its time, helping rebellions take over towns can get you some better gear at safe houses but it really doesnt change the dynamic of the districts, goverment autoritys still go after you and rebels dont help you during story missions like they should(This game tries to do what inFamous perfected). This game hasnt aged well and I'm not comparing it to newer games when I say this, but older ones, playing this game in 2006 would have made me say the same things. The physics of the cars, the bahavior of the ai, the shooter mechanics, lack of ducking and cover, uninteresting guns and useless sniper rifle, rediclous mission setups, uninteresting side characters, protentious and steriotypical spanish hot shot as a lead character with horrible one liners. The game just doesnt stack up well, you cant save when you want half the time and are usually forced to complete missions to save your progress, the only practical way to beat somee missions is to abuse exploits, sometimes your weapons will disapear for no reason, glitches appear with every ai interaction, you randomly appear in off places after some missions, oh Lord the missions.. There is some unbalance to be had in the missions, either so hard that it's random or easy that you know they didn't go through to iron some missions out, but NOTHING compares to the final mission, it expects you to traverse a entire warzoned island with bombs soldiers and tanks blowing everything up at complete random with no check points, and fly a high speed jet and sky dive on a air plane, it's all luck and no skill which all ends with a horrible and cheesy boss that you didn't even know was a villain until the end.While fun and stunt worthy this game can be, the bad piles up to high. Avoid.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Firstly, for it's time this was an ambitious project and would have been impressive. That asside I am reviewing it as it is now, for sale here on Steam.You play a preset character but there is hardly any example where you exhibit any personality at all so picking a character would hardly effect your experiece.You start immediately, thrown into the action, which is awkward. You'll find instantly that you have very limited options when disposing of your enemies which is a shame because it has the endlessly funny old ragdoll physics similar to Spiderman 2 and Mercenaries: Playground of Destruction. You need more tools and things to play with for combat, or murder, to be of any interest.If you're like me you'll do some research on the story as you play as putting things into context is important but the story is not likely to immerse you or entertain you.With this in mind you will be given a large map to basically capture by yourself. You will have followers that come and go... mostly go as you they try to protect your grenades from loud noises.There is no real reason to capture the map, it's just pointless busy work - you gain access to better weapons and vehicles but personally it didn't change much for me. You don't have to capture everything, however, you can follow the story (which does have you completing side quests) and you'll get through them without much trouble.If you must know, should you play Just Cause 2 without playing this you will not miss out. Read up on the game on Google if you wish.Overall I cannot recommend this game based on what I have played - note that dated graphics/physics don't bother me so long as the mechanics are fun. Just Cause 1: 3/10 - Ambitious, sometimes fun yet asks too much with far too little.Recommended alternatives: Mercenaries: Playground of Destrution - 8/10Just Cause 2 - 7/10

Posted: August 11, 2014
												Probably the worst game I have ever had the misfortune to play. Do not bother with it, skip straight to Just Cause 2, forget this was ever made. The side missions that let you gain control of regions are hugely repetitive. There seems to be no advantage to gaining control of regions, or doing tasks for the two factions you are supporting, other than getting better vehicles and access to safehouses. The driving mechanics feel floaty and leave you sliding all over the road. During these side missions, there is no checkpoint system, if you die, you will be transported to the nearest safehouse, leaving you often taking several minutes just to return to the area you were in, where you will promptly be randomly exploded again. Despite the somewhat random nature of death from vehicles or explosions, you can take ridiculous amounts of bullet hits before appearing injured, at which point your health will regenerate, but only to around 20%. Although your health doesn't regenerate, apart from some NPC drops there is no health-pack system, meaning the only way to return to full health is to go back to a safehouse and use a medical box there. The almost invulnerable period and the total lack of anything even remotely approaching a cover system means often the best technique when liberating settlements is just to run in and destroy the necessary items before capturing the flag, almost completely ignoring the enemy NPCs to complete it as quickly as possible. It doesn't feel like any progress is made when you're fighting the NPCs as not only can they take a huge amount of bullets too, but they seem to endlessly spawn, and will quite happily do so behind you, leaving you running around in the open shooting randomly (at which point you'll likely be run over and die). I'm not sure if they're glitches, but the police will constantly be shouting at you even if you have no "heat", and there is permanently a helicopter hovering somewhere near you. Which sometimes decides to shoot at those nearby. This probably wouldn't be a concern if I knew why it was there, if only I didn't have to constantly listen to a helicopter, which means if I'd like to peacefully explore the game's huge and impressive environment, I have to do it chaperoned by a damn noisy hovering annoyance. It's annoying when it turns out to be a police helicopter, which will start raining down missiles when you scratch someones car. There's a bizarre targeting system too, which sometimes auto-aims, and sometimes doesn't. Several times I blew myself up when the game decided I was aiming missiles at the guy who had just appeared three feet to my left, rather than the fuel tank which was my objective 50m away.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
												Just Cause is a 3rd person shooter with a forgivably cheese ball story and a lot of cool ideas. You play as Rico Rodriguez, a suave secret agent type on a mission to overthrow the dictator of the Caribbean island San Esperito. There's a giant open world, a set of factions warring against the currently established government, a grappling hook that can shoot you towards cars/boats/planes/etc, and a parachute you can pull anytime your high enough off the ground. Unfortunately, it is in the execution of these ideas that the game starts to fall apart.     To start, the world of San Esperito is truly massive and pretty impressive for such an old game (2006). This seems great until you realize that it consists mostly of long stretches of dense forests and tall mountains that make traversing it a huge pain. The various planes, jets, helicopters, and boats all do a well enough job at getting you from point A to point B, heck even jumping off a high mountain and gliding with your parachute is a pretty quick way to get around, but running on the other hand is completely off the table and the ground vehicles are arguably just as bad of an option with crazy amounts of oversteer making driving less of a convenience and more of a challenge.     San Esperito is also populated with a few cities, some villages, and a couple of army bases. These all start off as government/cartel controlled but can be taken over. This is accomplished by first completing the story mission in the given area which will shift the surrounding areas from "Government stable" to "Politically unstable", unlocking the liberation missions for the respective group you will be aiding in the takeover, either the Rebels or the Riojas (an anti-government drug cartel). During these mission you run in with your allies and try to raise hell by shooting as many enemies as you can and generally blowing‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•up. Again, this is a pretty cool idea, except in practice it can quickly turn into a‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•show. Accidentally shot one of your allies while he was running around wildly in front of the enemies you were trying to take down? It is now his sole purpose in life to kill you dead. Did an ally bump you with his slow moving car when riding in to join the fight? The wonky vehicle collision will almost ensure that even at full health, you wont be getting back up. All of this gets even more chaotic in later portions of the game when both the police/army and your allies start bringing tanks and attack choppers into the fights and a stray missile sends you straight back to your safe house. Your reward for soldering through these missions is an area full a friendly faction members and some faction points which you accumulate in order to rise through the ranks of that particular faction, unlocking bases, weapons, and vehicles along the way.     Aside from these issues, the combat can actually be pretty fun and creative. The shooting is pretty basic (Headshots aren't a thing? come on!) with dropped health packs in favor of regenerating health, but cool tricks like throwing a grenade and then shooting it in mid air or raining bullets from above as you parachute across the battlefield help to spice things up. You can also highjack anything with an engine by aiming your trusty grappling gun at it and then reeling yourself in close enough to jump in the drivers seat, or just hitching a ride. This can add a whole new layer of mobility and strategy to large scale battles that you don't really see in most games. Its a shame that you can only use the grappling gun directly on vehicles as this could have led to some very inventive stuff.      Just Cause also makes sure to include the obligatory racing missions and collectables we see in most open world games. The races are pretty basic; you are the only participant racing to get to the next checkpoint on the map before a timer runs out. As tacked on as these are, I actually found them somewhat fun even though 8 of the 9 races involve the previously mentioned terrible driving mechanics. The collectables are out in the open for the most part and kind of a bore to collect. They don't really add anything to the game but you do get some faction points for collecting a full set. Speaking of which, before and after a liberation becomes available, the factions contact will be waiting nearby the settlements they are assigned to and will allow you to partake in side missions for some faction points. These boil down to fetch quests and "go kill/blow up X/Y", which are far from the most exciting things to do but will once in a while lead to an interesting offshoot, like "go kill X" but this time he's on a lightly guarded tanker on the ocean.     The core game is pretty short taking less than 5hrs to get through if you choose to ignore the fluff, like taking over settlements etc, in favor of rushing through the story missions. I also ran into problems with the games sound where I would be miles above the ground in a plane and hear a police officer shouting as though he was standing right next to me; not to mention not once being able to tell where a helicopter was in the sky based on the blaring propeller noises coming from seemingly nowhere. There were a few glitches as well where I would spawn inside buildings, fail to respawn completely, or have my helicopter zoom off into a wall or the ocean on its own after landing and getting out, but these were infrequent enough not to be much of a problem.     Overall, Just Cause has not aged very well. It can be a fun game when everything works as intended but it's short story with repetitive side content and a general lack of polish in some key areas all wrapped up in an 8 year old game keep me from being able to recommend this. 4/10.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												When reviewing "old" games, I tend to be tolerant in regards to technical aspects such as graphical fidelity, animation quality and overall presentation.Just Cause, released in 2006, is not a bad looker. Cranked up to the max, its video settings allow for some pretty stunning vistas in the huge tropical island of San Esperito.However, that's pretty much where the praise ends.The story has no depth at all. You're a US agent and your mission is to overthrow a Latin American dictator. Along the way, you'll be assigned some the most forgettable seek-and-destroy missions the gaming world has ever seen, usually consisting of:1. Being briefed by terribly voice-acted, stereotypized characters;2. Getting to terms with the nearest vehicle's shoddy handling in order to reach your objective as quickly as possible;3. Storming a government base, guns blazing (forget about stealth), walking through fire from a hundred mindless, respawning enemies (good luck getting cover from helicopter miniguns, though), planting a few C4 charges and leaving.That's it. Very simplistic gameplay coupled with terrible artifical intelligence. That's Just Cause in a nutshell.I wouldn't recommend it by 2006's standards, and I most certainly won't recommend it now.

Just Cause leaves little reason to buy unless it's 'just cause.'Pros: GraphicsCons: Controls, Story, Gameplay, BugsFor a game released in 2006, Just Cause looks great in some places: the water and the sky look amazing.  Other places, however, are best rushed over.Just Cause is simply a bad port of a relatively old and mediocre game.  The controls are awful; even the AI seems to have trouble driving.  The story is copy-paste: military badass defeats evil dictator and his lackeys.  The gameplay is boring and unbalanced.  Huge stretches of terrain separate virtually identical 'liberations' that have no impact on the story.  Enemies can deliver small scratches or one-hit kills.  There are no difficulty settings.  As previously mentioned, the game is a bad port: no resolution support, no controller support, and a number of bugs.As the game's cast may put it, Just Cause is a 'gigundo' mess.6/10
