												This game is one of these titles that are good, but just not good enough..Simplifying my experience and trying to be short:pros:-A very nice setting, the nature design and the size of the map are nice for a 2006 game of the genre. You can keep hearing shouts "freeze citizen!" and "alto alto! this nis the police!" even if you are like alone in the freakin woods, hell you even hear them when you are driving a plane 10 miles above ground. You also get to hear vehicle sounds that are unnaturally far away from you.-Too many helicopters flying around. I mean seriously, TOO MANY.-Grappling hook only works on moving vehicles. 												I really wanted to like this game.  The promise of a fun an entertaining game is under the hood, and that is what laid the foundation for a much better game in Just Cause 2.  Unfortunetly this one is riddled with issues that cannot be overlooked.Pro's:Big Open World that encourages and rewards exploration with many things to do.Full City Liberation missions are fun unlike the military base ones.Cons:Horrible A.I. for both friendlies and enemies.  Friendly A.I. will run you over in cars they took during liberation missions meanwhile enemy A.I. is just a tad bit more intelligent than the A.I. in Aliens Colonial Marines which has one of the worst enemy A.I's of all time.Enemy Helicopters can follow you around the whole map and can pinpoint you even under heavy foliageSide Missions are highly repetitive and lose their lustre,  especially when trying to liberate a military base where you can't tell who's friendly or enemy based on clashing color schemes.Vehicles handle like garbage.  Seriously why does a light tap on the keyboard induce a power slide on a jeep.This game stutters during combat after about an hour of gameplay and this issue can only be fixed with a restart.All in all this game is best left unplayed.  If you want to play a finished and more polished version of this game than I recommend you just play Just Cause 2.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												Really?I load up GTA Vice City, and I am able to reasonably begin playing. San Andreas and many more titles from this time period have recieved at least a bit of controller support updating. (even if it was usually a community effort)Obviously people are going to WANT to play this game.  I absolutely love JC2, and I want to be able to play this game.  It is beautiful and much more appealing than GTA as an open-world title I can share with my kids. (GTA has too much bad language and insinuations I prefer my kids don't hear at their age)I can't even select the top resolution 1600 x 1200, and I needed a quick file from the web to 1920 x 1080 it.Even with a KB mapper, my controller is not gradually easing on a curve, or slowly accelerating.  It is an ON/Off thing.You are either FULL ON or FULL OFF on what would normally be an expected analog experience.  driving is a nightmare once up to speed, and I try to save my wrists from extra KB&M work.  This is not comfortable AT ALL.The game loads great, and with the fix it is really beautiful to look at.  I played a very short time before I just couldn't take it.  There is nothing about this that is going to make me want to finish the title.With so many people gearing up for JC3, don't you think a big name company could afford a little bit of effort to bring this experience up to standard?This is yet another time where I have attempted to go back to earlier titles and have been let down due to lacking support.  Plenty of big IPs have received some sort of touching up, there is really no excuse.  Outdated visuals are fine, but lacking basic controller support is unfair.  How is there not even support for my older Gravis or other gamepads?  The game seriously came out back then WITHOUT ANY CONTROLLER SUPPORT??? Why would a company decide to release a game on a console, and then not offer PC players the comfort of a controller?  This is junk thinking.Unless the game gets an update, or you don't mind KB&M or the process of KB mapping, just get the game on a console (I rarely say that)

content:
Posted: May 25, 2013
												Please note: I did not play this game when it first released in 2006, so this review will be written from that perspective.For an open world game, the main story campaign of Just Cause has only 21 missions and can be completed in just 7 hours. It was originally released in 2006, but compared to a similar open-world styled game GTA San Andreas which was released earlier in 2004, Just Cause is clearly a much more inferior game in comparison.Even though the story of Just Cause wasn't supposed to be anything special other then a typical action game, but it looked like they didn't even bother to try to at least pretend to tell a story. Every single mission is about 2 people sunbathing and drinking wine and telling you to blow‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•up. Yes i'm not kidding.There are alot of things wrong with it. Firstly, it is a very poor console port, where you can't even use the mouse on the main menu. Graphics look painfully inadequate even by 2006 standards especially the enemies death animations where every single one of them does this same "jump back horizontally look" when they die.Vehicle handling is atrocious, cars and airplanes are just way too sensitive in their controls. Also, try driving a motorcycle around, and look at what happens when an oncoming truck rams you....wait for it. Nothing happens. Your motorcycle just goes to a sudden stop. Just Cause really feels like one of those 1st generation substandard Open-World GTA clones and is a very good example of how NOT to do an open world game.That said, it introduces the now series trademark stunt hijacking of vehicles which will probably feel very fresh when released in 2006, but is let down by the fact that the vehicles themselves are really no fun to drive in. The eclectic latino sounding soundtrack however is pretty good and i did enjoy listening to that.I know it may not be fair for me to review this game in 2012, which is close to 6 years after its original release. Then again, playing Just Cause 1 lets me appreciate Just Cause 2 even more lol. I must say that I am happy that Avalanche Studios saw what was wrong in JC1 and made JC2 a much better game and carve out its own unique identity.Overall Rating: 3.0 / 10Horrible game. Don't buy it even If you are thinking of getting it because you enjoyed Just Cause 2. You won't miss out on any story elements or anything and you're better off just playing Just Cause 2 instead.

 Nothing special about this game. It is playable to say the best. Cons:- Open world game with no reason to explore other than activating missions.- Missions are repetitive, specially faction mission, which happens always with the same npc, giving even less reason to explore the world.- You can't shoot while on cars, while your enemies can. Or i didn't find out how to do it. You're defenseless while in car.- It has "turret missions" with auto-aiming. Just hold the mouse button and you'll win.- The diversity of stunts are limited.- Shooting is bland, no cover, just run and gun. Very arcade.- Bugged, some vehicles don't work. There are some physics bug that makes your vehicle fly all over the map (can be a bit funny tho').- You can't run nor can't crouch. Going anywhere on foot takes forever.- Unbalanced. Spawning feast of enemies all over you. You dont get any sort of upgrades such as armors.- Playing with mouse and keyboard is possible, but it is really bad. (i've finished the game with K+m)Pros:- It has physics for such old game (details such as car's window and doors breaking)- Open world- Good vehicle variety, helos, tanks, planes, boats. Including some armed vehicles, such as military ones.Unless you're REALLY into this kind of game and has run out of options: Don't waste your time.Avoid it as much as possible.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												This was truly a game that got better with the sequels. Though I am happy that Eidos went through with the subsequent sequels, it's safe to say that this game is only worth it for the terrible plot, voice acting, and trying to master the art of getting into flying vehicles with the grappling hook. Aside from that, the side quests are tedious and not worth doing, the travel time from key mission to key mission is mind numbing, and the countless glitches. I'm currently stuck on the second to last level of the game because it's missing key cutscenes. As for other bugs, certain cars with turrets will glitch by rotating uncontrollably and messing with the turning mechanics of the car. I would switch to the rocket mode of the tank, and it hurled me into the sea with its violent rotations - like a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• nonsensical helicopter. Also, sometimes when you try to steal someone elses car, the door comes flying off. The resolution is a minor gripe, but the game is still beautiful for the time that it was in.  Just Cause this game will be cheap as hell, doesn't mean you should buy it. Really - skip this one. You'll save yourself hours of frustration over a plot you don't care about.

It has some of the worst driving mechanics and physics, and getting hit by a car is most of the times instakill. Do you think bullets kill you in this game? Oh no, most of my deaths were at the hand of my allies, that decided to park their car over my body during liberations. And they always park exactly at the point I was standing on. So the most important advice for this game is: NEVER STAY ON THE ROAD DURING LIBERATIONS.When it comes to the map, Just Cause devs thought that having a bigger map would make the game better, but it backfires right at the beginning of the game, once you realize that locations are too far from each other and going from A to B is a chore. Wouldn't be too bad if the map wasn't so lazy. All settlements and villas look almost identical with slight differences. There were some interesting points on the map that felt like a mission would take place there, but were completely unused. If the map was halved it would have been much more convenient and enjoyable. It's really not worth playing, unless you just want to breeze through the story, which is pretty short. I ended up 100% the game, which is not worth it when you don't get rewarded. However, Just Cause 2 is much much better and worth every cent. Or just wait for Just Cause 3 and play that one if it ends up being good. No point playing all of them in this case.

												'Just Cause' is the story of Che Guevara, an Argentine Marxist revolutionary, physician, author, guerrilla leader, diplomat, and military theorist. A major figure of the Cuban Revolution, his stylized visage has become a ubiquitous countercultural symbol of rebellion and global insignia in popular culture.Playing Che as a young medical student, you travel throughout South America and become radicalized by the poverty, hunger, and disease that you witness. Most of this part of the game consists of quicktime events punctuated by scenes of you jogging down corridors and along dusty streets, but the tight controls more than make up for any boredom you might feel. Your burgeoning desire to help overturn what you see as the capitalist exploitation of Latin America by the United States prompts your involvement in Guatemala's social reforms under President Jacobo √Årbenz, and at this point in the game you join one of three factions which you will stay as for the rest of the game. In my playthrough I joined the 'Reapers' which was more of a fetch-quest based plot but I really like these because I'm a masochist.The president's eventual CIA-assisted overthrow at the behest of the United Fruit Company solidifies your political ideology and you can start earning perks that upgrade Che based on three trees - Ideology, Philosophy and Taxation Schemes. Ideology allows you to increase Che's intelligence making things like lockpicking and sneaking easier. Philosophy makes people dislike Che more but you're able to find things like hidden doors and alternative roads thanks to 'thinking outside of the box'. Taxation Schemes are probably the most useful tree and are fairly self-explanatory.Later, in Mexico City, you meet Ra√∫l and Fidel Castro, join their 26th of July Movement, and sail to Cuba aboard the yacht, Granma, with the intention of overthrowing U.S.-backed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. The yacht becomes a hub for you and your men and from here you can use an extensive crafting system to make new weapons. Whilst the other NPCs are in your party you can outfit them with weapons and skills just as you can for Che. The AI is a little patchy in places but for the most part works fine. You soon rise to prominence among the insurgents, get promoted to second-in-command, and play a pivotal role in the victorious two-year guerrilla campaign that is set on deposing the Batista regime. At this point the game moves to a top-down perspective ala Sim City, and most of the gameplay from now on is based around maps of military strategies and other boring stuff. I guess it's alright.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												In the standard tradition of Steam Summer Sales reinvigorating Bargain Bin Breakdowns I bring you, Just Cause.  I picked up the first two in the series, and their included DLC content for an amount low enough not care what the games were. Having been part of a franchise that I recognized I knew they couldn‚Äôt be total crap, right?Purchased and installed they sat there, icons on the desktop, being ignored while double clicks would happen elsewhere.  Two icons over LEGO Worlds gets a double click, on the other side of the screen Quake 4 is the proud recipient of a click followed by and press of ‚ÄòEnter‚Äô on the keyboard.  Team Fortress 2, Fallout 3, Resident Evil 4, Race to the White House, Minecraft, Chips Challenge, even the Recycling Bin were all getting more click-action.  Until I finally decided to hover the cursor atop its icon and give it the grace of the double-click.  Why, after all this time did I finally take this step?  Just cause.As of writing I‚Äôve logged five hours playing Just Cause and while that‚Äôs not enough time to provide a fair and honest review, I‚Äôm gonna do one anyway.  Just cause.Things start off with a free fall from the back of a plane where I need to meet up with a contact on a beach.  The first time I did this I opened my parachute earlier than I meant to, then closed it and reopened it again, and again and again, and again. I guess Rico(the main character) has a hundred reserve chutes or maybe he can fold them up and repack them quickly?  After a while I just decided to belly flop into the ocean, die, and start this crazy mess over.  Only I didn‚Äôt die.  Falling from really high up, gaining speed by holding my body tight and pointing down and I just splash like it was a five foot high dive.I stared at the screen for a moment or two, awe struck, slightly annoyed. Seconds went by and I noticed the lack of a breathing reminder. So I waited, and waited, and waited some more.  Never did I see anything informing me of a need to exit the water to breath nor did I suffer to the fate of suffocation.  I‚Äôm going to hope the developers went with this route because of some aspect of the game I haven‚Äôt experienced yet, and not just cause.Once I restarted and made it to the beach proper I helped my contact guy fight off some other people and then we left in his truck. During the truck ride I got to see the auto-aiming performed by the mounted gun in the back of the truck. I‚Äôm starting to notice a trend of ‚Äòeasy mode‚Äô, is this because I‚Äôm playing on an easy difficulty?  Maybe, I don‚Äôt know, but I‚Äôm not complaining about it.  I‚Äôve reached the point where I‚Äôd rather have a enjoyable casual gaming experience than getting worked up because its too much of a challenge.We make it to the base or hideout, or whatever it is, where I get a cut scene leading me into the first real mission.  What that actually is I haven‚Äôt a clue since I‚Äôm focused on how this guy talking to me is completely trying to be Sam Axe from Burn Notice. But whatever, lets get this pony show on the road.  I leave that place check around my surrounding and find a motorcycle, so I hop on and start driving towards the point marked on my map, just cause.At some point I passed a police car and they yelled ‚ÄúStop!‚Äù and hit the lights/sirens combo.  I thought ‚ÄòWow, that‚Äôs awesome it detected me speeding, this is going to a fun challenge to play!‚Äò So I stopped, and the police car pulled up and they got out.  I got off my motorcycle, not knowing what to expect, then they shot me. I guess I should have expected this.  Although I don‚Äôt know what it was that triggered them to attack me, but the police yelling at you constantly is an annoying part of the game, just cause.I think it was somewhere around here that I realized I was playing a mob-less tropical-island-based Grand Theft Auto. Don‚Äôt immediately take that as a bad thing, the GTA franchise is one of the best ones out there.  And sure, there are other games out there that put you in an open world like that, Mafia is another that comes to mind.  But I mark GTA with that distinction since it was at least the first one I played.The main story didn‚Äôt grab me as I had hoped, I went and broke some guy out of prison and instead of him wondering why I would do that having never met me, he had me join him.  Which was good, since the reason why I was to break him out was so I trick him into letting me join his group. I feel like the leader of a rebel group would question the guy  he‚Äôs never met before that breaks him out of prison. I guess he decided to just cause.I did a couple main story line missions before I discovered the side missions.  Missions where you help liberate small villages from different armies or something.  Those were fun, repetitive, but fun. You would basically work your way up a road taking out roadblocks along the way until you reached either a flag that needed capturing or a leader that needed killing.  I would fly my helicopter to a mission marked on the map, liberate the town, and then steal the helicopter parked on the roof of the building.  Then fly off to the next one. I did this for a couple hours, and I had more fun than I had playing the main storyline. I‚Äôm not trashing the story or anything, it just didn‚Äôt grab me like liberation missions did.From what I‚Äôve seen Just Cause is the child of Far Cry and Grand Theft Auto‚Äôs wild night in Vegas. They‚Äôve taken pieces from both and created this whole new thing. Its not terrible, its not amazing, it just is, just cause.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												Short Review:The game is dated and its age clearly shows. When I first got the game, the user reviews were mostly positive. Now it's mixed, so you can probably tell from that too. Full Review:- Gameplay & GraphicsWhile the scenes in the video look nice, playing it in 2014 with a 1680 x 1050 resolution and later in 2015 with a 1920 x 1080 resolution makes me feel like crying. If you force the game to full screen, it's pixelated, else it's small. I could adjust my default screen resolution to suit the game, but this simply reinforces that the game is outdated. It may be good in 2006, but certainly not now. The controls are your typical WASD and mouse interaction, while for the gameplay itself, I did not fully explore the game so I cannot offer a full storyline review. However, from my early stages in the game, it takes way too long to travel from one point to another with little to offer. While Far Cry also requires you to walk a long distance, at least you get to hunt some game. Not in Just Cause 1. It's just holding W and hoping someday, you get there.- AudioThe music and sound effects are pretty average in my opinion. I'm not a fan of it, but taste is subjective.- VerdictDon't buy it, even it's for a really cheap 90% discount. Unless you're using an older and smaller computer, you've played it before and you want to play it again. In that case, follow your desire.

content:
Posted: March 22
												The only reason to play this game in 2017, ten years after its release is for a sense of nostalgia. Here are my notes from playing the game.  The base game looks extremely dull. This is a port of the original Xbox version and it looks bad even for a 2005 game. The game has no controller support and it is better to play with a keyboard and mouse. I had to look at the forums to fix  the widescreen and shadow problems and had to use SweetFX to brighten things a bit. Animation and AI feel so old, its nostalgic. It appears to be on par with Mass Effect: Andromeda. :P The game features very silly plot and dialog with funny looking character models. Bare minimum of instructions, I didn't know I had to free the first area before I could save the game. There is constant police & helicopter noise in the background and it is very annoying. Capturing the various areas is fun at first but gets repetitive fast. I don't remember seeing a difficulty setting. It was extremely easy. Guns have autoaim and it is enough to shoot somewhere near the enemies. There is no regenerating health except for a tiny portion but enemies drop health packs regularly. Grappling hook is not as good as in JC2 but it can be used to skyjack helicopters. The world is vast but feels lifeless compared to GTA and the first Saints Row from around the same time. Four wheelers handle very poorly, there is no way to set a waypoint and the map is barely functional. Fortunately, there is something like taxi in GTA to avoid driving yourself. Every session after playing for an hour or two, the game begins to feel like its going to crash soon, this is remedied by restarting the game. The game crashed unexpectedly 2 times in total, not bad for a 10 year old game.Just the main story takes around 8 hours to finish. Liberating the areas is not really necessary for progress. I had extremely low expectations and the game is okay for what it is.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Got this and it's sequel in a bundle a long time ago, figured it was time to check them out now that #3 has dropped and looks fun.Observations - not going pro/con as in this case I feel that's a bit subjective:- Game shows it's age (2006) by not supporting bigger resolutions.- Map is surprisingly HUGE and not in a good way really. It takes forever to get places, even with a chopper or really fast boat- Half the time I feel like Superman, the other I'm getting run over and killed by my supporting AI- Audio is annoying, music from certain areas sometimes sticks with you as you move about- Random NPC phrases get extremely repetative and annoying in areas of population- Unlimited pistol ammo, but very limited assult/SMG/etc ammo- Unlike the Far Cry series which I can in some ways compare this to, the green forrest aren't at all worth visiting are are very boring with zero variety- Not a lot is explained, each mission will have details but you have to open the menu, then open mission info to learn details- Voice acting from the very dated CGI cuts scenes is poor, but not terrible for the period- Buggy with lots of pop-in/drop-out artifacts, mainly cars and enemies. I called in a truck, drove it 200 feet and it died, won't move. Figured ok, got another ride, quit the game later, saving, played again after a while, called in truck, it's still dead, really?- Map is SO big and it takes you SO long to traverse it on foot that you need vehicles or use the fast travel/agency pick-up system, otherwise it gets BORING wandering around pretty quick.- Side missions include checkpoint races, fetch quests and kill quests. They never end, so you can do them over and over and that's annoying for completionists like myself. Worse you won't know which you've already done and it's hard to see the benefits until you visit a safehouse.- Driving physics/controls are comically poor, if you get a flat rear tire on a rear drive vehicle enjoy unbarable oversteer, overall every land/sea vehicle has felt very floaty, getting airborn often gives a lame slow-mo shot, crashing off a cliff and getting the car to roll leads to funny physics.- The chopper controls are decent, but if you jump out and depoly your parachute it's really hard to gauge how high up your are, so don't let go until you land.I can see the roots of some cool gameplay elements and features that I suspect have helped define this franchise. However if you make this your first game in the series be preparred to have frustrations. So far for me the frustrations haven't led to rage quits or anything and the difficulty so far has been reasonable - EDIT: essentially rage quit the last time, frustrating difficulty, uninstalling game, updating this review, moving on.Recommend?EDIT: I had to change this review. Simply can't recommend this game, it's ENTIRELY TOO HUGE, it takes forever to traverse even with a chopper, forget a car as you almost 100% have to stay on the roads, and F walking, it takes FOREVER - I ended up setting something on my E key to keep moving forward when boringly trying to get somewhere.Bugs - pull a guy out of a ride and watch his door go flying, get into a APV, get bumped and watch your several ton armored vehicle roll, even fly around, don't walk near a road or get insta-killed by being run over, revive at a safe house only to land inside the structure, stuck.Difficulty ramped up a TON after I gained control of approximately 50% of the map. When it takes you 5 mins to get from a spawn point/safe house via chopper to your takeover area only to have your mission ramp to level 5 (top threat level) within 30 seconds and have rockets fired at you from God only knows where and die. Then take another 5 mins to get back there to get closer but still die - it's no longer fun and therefore not worth the time, I have way too many other games that I know are better waiting, including hopefully a greatly improved Just Cause 2.My progress:My first review was after 7.4 hours in, this update is after over 20 hours. I think I made it around 40-45% through the story missions and I collected around 85% of the pickups while liberating right around 50+% of the map, done several side quests too getting my militia and gang supports up pretty high. I struggled to put aside my completionish mentality and focus on the story, but avoided extra side missons, instead just aiming to liberate all of the locations. After having the difficulty ramp up so much in the last few missions/liberation attempts I just can't see wasting anymore time trying to do really anything else. I tried, but the game defeated me...

Posted: October 15, 2015
												'Just Cause' is the story of Che Guevara, an Argentine Marxist revolutionary, physician, author, guerrilla leader, diplomat, and military theorist. A major figure of the Cuban Revolution, his stylized visage has become a ubiquitous countercultural symbol of rebellion and global insignia in popular culture.Playing Che as a young medical student, you travel throughout South America and become radicalized by the poverty, hunger, and disease that you witness. Most of this part of the game consists of quicktime events punctuated by scenes of you jogging down corridors and along dusty streets, but the tight controls more than make up for any boredom you might feel. Your burgeoning desire to help overturn what you see as the capitalist exploitation of Latin America by the United States prompts your involvement in Guatemala's social reforms under President Jacobo √Årbenz, and at this point in the game you join one of three factions which you will stay as for the rest of the game. In my playthrough I joined the 'Reapers' which was more of a fetch-quest based plot but I really like these because I'm a masochist.The president's eventual CIA-assisted overthrow at the behest of the United Fruit Company solidifies your political ideology and you can start earning perks that upgrade Che based on three trees - Ideology, Philosophy and Taxation Schemes. Ideology allows you to increase Che's intelligence making things like lockpicking and sneaking easier. Philosophy makes people dislike Che more but you're able to find things like hidden doors and alternative roads thanks to 'thinking outside of the box'. Taxation Schemes are probably the most useful tree and are fairly self-explanatory.Later, in Mexico City, you meet Ra√∫l and Fidel Castro, join their 26th of July Movement, and sail to Cuba aboard the yacht, Granma, with the intention of overthrowing U.S.-backed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. The yacht becomes a hub for you and your men and from here you can use an extensive crafting system to make new weapons. Whilst the other NPCs are in your party you can outfit them with weapons and skills just as you can for Che. The AI is a little patchy in places but for the most part works fine. You soon rise to prominence among the insurgents, get promoted to second-in-command, and play a pivotal role in the victorious two-year guerrilla campaign that is set on deposing the Batista regime. At this point the game moves to a top-down perspective ala Sim City, and most of the gameplay from now on is based around maps of military strategies and other boring stuff. I guess it's alright.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I'll be frank. The original Just Cause was extremely advanced for the time, allowing for vertical gameplay, an absolutely MASSIVE world map, capture-the-territory regime change mechanics, car stunts and a politicized CIA story archetype which is pretty distinctive in its conceptualization by Avalanche Studios. I originally played this game for the Xbox 360 at a friend's house and was completely blown away by the freedom the game afforded, its solid controls and its then-gorgeous graphical detail.The PC port does it a disservice by being so janky. I personally believe it's almost impossible to advance in the game because the vehicular and combat controls were originally designed for the 360 version and were then effectively rebound to a mouse and keyboard as the only change... this makes the entire game feel stiff and hard-to-adapt-to when you're actually playing it.Combine this with numerous graphical, AI, UI and other kinds of issues (Regular crashes to desktop? Really?) and you have, without hyperbole, what is one of the worst PC ports I have ever seen. I would gladly recommend you play this game, just not this version of it. It's overpriced at $6.99 unless you really don't care about it being playable and only want to collect it.If you loved Just Cause 2 and want to harken back to the genesis of the franchise, go do yourself a favor and pick up the Xbox 360 version. Maybe that's mostly nostalgia talking (I have yet to have bought the 360 copy for myself after all this time), but you have a far greater chance of beating what is an ultimately good game hampered by an awful port. Oh yeah, and you can't do 16:9 in this game either. Yep. At least the PS2 version (also flawed, but much easier to play) had an excuse, being a last-gen port.

The map is very big, but almost all of it is forest/jungle. The collectibles, liberation quests and side missions are also very repetitive, with the exception of a few races. However, one could see the potential that a sequel would deliver, and Just Cause 2 did that. Still, i can recommend the original for cheap if you play the story missions, because the rest was a chore for me to play.

												'Just Cause' is the story of Che Guevara, an Argentine Marxist revolutionary, physician, author, guerrilla leader, diplomat, and military theorist. A major figure of the Cuban Revolution, his stylized visage has become a ubiquitous countercultural symbol of rebellion and global insignia in popular culture.Playing Che as a young medical student, you travel throughout South America and become radicalized by the poverty, hunger, and disease that you witness. Most of this part of the game consists of quicktime events punctuated by scenes of you jogging down corridors and along dusty streets, but the tight controls more than make up for any boredom you might feel. Your burgeoning desire to help overturn what you see as the capitalist exploitation of Latin America by the United States prompts your involvement in Guatemala's social reforms under President Jacobo √Årbenz, and at this point in the game you join one of three factions which you will stay as for the rest of the game. In my playthrough I joined the 'Reapers' which was more of a fetch-quest based plot but I really like these because I'm a masochist.The president's eventual CIA-assisted overthrow at the behest of the United Fruit Company solidifies your political ideology and you can start earning perks that upgrade Che based on three trees - Ideology, Philosophy and Taxation Schemes. Ideology allows you to increase Che's intelligence making things like lockpicking and sneaking easier. Philosophy makes people dislike Che more but you're able to find things like hidden doors and alternative roads thanks to 'thinking outside of the box'. Taxation Schemes are probably the most useful tree and are fairly self-explanatory.Later, in Mexico City, you meet Ra√∫l and Fidel Castro, join their 26th of July Movement, and sail to Cuba aboard the yacht, Granma, with the intention of overthrowing U.S.-backed Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. The yacht becomes a hub for you and your men and from here you can use an extensive crafting system to make new weapons. Whilst the other NPCs are in your party you can outfit them with weapons and skills just as you can for Che. The AI is a little patchy in places but for the most part works fine. You soon rise to prominence among the insurgents, get promoted to second-in-command, and play a pivotal role in the victorious two-year guerrilla campaign that is set on deposing the Batista regime. At this point the game moves to a top-down perspective ala Sim City, and most of the gameplay from now on is based around maps of military strategies and other boring stuff. I guess it's alright.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												Got this and it's sequel in a bundle a long time ago, figured it was time to check them out now that #3 has dropped and looks fun.Observations - not going pro/con as in this case I feel that's a bit subjective:- Game shows it's age (2006) by not supporting bigger resolutions.- Map is surprisingly HUGE and not in a good way really. It takes forever to get places, even with a chopper or really fast boat- Half the time I feel like Superman, the other I'm getting run over and killed by my supporting AI- Audio is annoying, music from certain areas sometimes sticks with you as you move about- Random NPC phrases get extremely repetative and annoying in areas of population- Unlimited pistol ammo, but very limited assult/SMG/etc ammo- Unlike the Far Cry series which I can in some ways compare this to, the green forrest aren't at all worth visiting are are very boring with zero variety- Not a lot is explained, each mission will have details but you have to open the menu, then open mission info to learn details- Voice acting from the very dated CGI cuts scenes is poor, but not terrible for the period- Buggy with lots of pop-in/drop-out artifacts, mainly cars and enemies. I called in a truck, drove it 200 feet and it died, won't move. Figured ok, got another ride, quit the game later, saving, played again after a while, called in truck, it's still dead, really?- Map is SO big and it takes you SO long to traverse it on foot that you need vehicles or use the fast travel/agency pick-up system, otherwise it gets BORING wandering around pretty quick.- Side missions include checkpoint races, fetch quests and kill quests. They never end, so you can do them over and over and that's annoying for completionists like myself. Worse you won't know which you've already done and it's hard to see the benefits until you visit a safehouse.- Driving physics/controls are comically poor, if you get a flat rear tire on a rear drive vehicle enjoy unbarable oversteer, overall every land/sea vehicle has felt very floaty, getting airborn often gives a lame slow-mo shot, crashing off a cliff and getting the car to roll leads to funny physics.- The chopper controls are decent, but if you jump out and depoly your parachute it's really hard to gauge how high up your are, so don't let go until you land.I can see the roots of some cool gameplay elements and features that I suspect have helped define this franchise. However if you make this your first game in the series be preparred to have frustrations. So far for me the frustrations haven't led to rage quits or anything and the difficulty so far has been reasonable - EDIT: essentially rage quit the last time, frustrating difficulty, uninstalling game, updating this review, moving on.Recommend?EDIT: I had to change this review. Simply can't recommend this game, it's ENTIRELY TOO HUGE, it takes forever to traverse even with a chopper, forget a car as you almost 100% have to stay on the roads, and F walking, it takes FOREVER - I ended up setting something on my E key to keep moving forward when boringly trying to get somewhere.Bugs - pull a guy out of a ride and watch his door go flying, get into a APV, get bumped and watch your several ton armored vehicle roll, even fly around, don't walk near a road or get insta-killed by being run over, revive at a safe house only to land inside the structure, stuck.Difficulty ramped up a TON after I gained control of approximately 50% of the map. When it takes you 5 mins to get from a spawn point/safe house via chopper to your takeover area only to have your mission ramp to level 5 (top threat level) within 30 seconds and have rockets fired at you from God only knows where and die. Then take another 5 mins to get back there to get closer but still die - it's no longer fun and therefore not worth the time, I have way too many other games that I know are better waiting, including hopefully a greatly improved Just Cause 2.My progress:My first review was after 7.4 hours in, this update is after over 20 hours. I think I made it around 40-45% through the story missions and I collected around 85% of the pickups while liberating right around 50+% of the map, done several side quests too getting my militia and gang supports up pretty high. I struggled to put aside my completionish mentality and focus on the story, but avoided extra side missons, instead just aiming to liberate all of the locations. After having the difficulty ramp up so much in the last few missions/liberation attempts I just can't see wasting anymore time trying to do really anything else. I tried, but the game defeated me...

												I absolutely loved Just Cause 2,and after year's of this just sitting there,I decided to fire it up whilst I anxiously waited for my pay to come through to purchase Just Cause 3 on special from another site. The first 2 hour's or so were fun until I realised it was just going to be the same thing over and over and the glaring issue's grinded me down to the point where I couldn't overlook or put up with them any more. Firstly,the driving is absolutely terrible,oh my! Don't even get me started on trying to ride a motorbike. You need it to get to most places as well,so it becomes tedious real quick,and I found myself dreading it. Falling off any height in a vehicle looks ridiculous,does no damage whatsoever no matter how high the drop and takes ages to readjust into a position where you can drive/ride again. The control's in general are clunky,from jumping,parachuting to grappling (which is a standalone "weapon" and needs to be equipped as a gun replacement to use and just sucks in general). No matter what keybind I assigned to reel it in or out,they wouldn't work.  The only fun part was firing weapon's,and blowing stuff up,but the gameplay is extremely limited and It gets way too repetitive. It all feels exactly the same,and it's not good enough to keep doing over and over. The only real redeeming factor was how well it ran and looked (not including the pre-rendered cutscenes) with absolutely everything cranked in Nvidia Inspector.

												I absolutely loved Just Cause 2,and after year's of this just sitting there,I decided to fire it up whilst I anxiously waited for my pay to come through to purchase Just Cause 3 on special from another site. The first 2 hour's or so were fun until I realised it was just going to be the same thing over and over and the glaring issue's grinded me down to the point where I couldn't overlook or put up with them any more. Firstly,the driving is absolutely terrible,oh my! Don't even get me started on trying to ride a motorbike. You need it to get to most places as well,so it becomes tedious real quick,and I found myself dreading it. Falling off any height in a vehicle looks ridiculous,does no damage whatsoever no matter how high the drop and takes ages to readjust into a position where you can drive/ride again. The control's in general are clunky,from jumping,parachuting to grappling (which is a standalone "weapon" and needs to be equipped as a gun replacement to use and just sucks in general). No matter what keybind I assigned to reel it in or out,they wouldn't work.  The only fun part was firing weapon's,and blowing stuff up,but the gameplay is extremely limited and It gets way too repetitive. It all feels exactly the same,and it's not good enough to keep doing over and over. The only real redeeming factor was how well it ran and looked (not including the pre-rendered cutscenes) with absolutely everything cranked in Nvidia Inspector.

However, one could see the potential that a sequel would deliver, and Just Cause 2 did that. Still, i can recommend the original for cheap if you play the story missions, because the rest was a chore for me to play.

content:
Posted: January 2
												Recommend or not...Since I completed the main mission and did have fun overall, I'll say "Yes". However, the game didn't aged well. There are much better game out there.Yet, I cannot say that I didn't enjoyed most of the game. Even if at the end I was getting a bit tired of its redundancy and some of its old gameplay mechanics. It's fun. But the fun doesn't last long enough.If you buy it, you'll get a VAST open world to explore. They say "Over 250K acres of land to explore", well, you can believe them. It will take you a few day of just moving around to see every corner of it. Helping the guerilla faction and the drug cartel helps you by giving you access to new equipment, but also their presence on the territory will help you keep the military busy while you try to move around. This makes you want to help them. That is great.On the graphic side, the game looks good despite its age. The environnement is amazing and the water look real enough. If the fact of capturing the country region by region is great, the story itself is pretty boring and unmoving. The main missions can probably be completed in about 5 or 6 hours. However, if you want to explore the entire world and complete every side mission, it should keep you occupied for quite sometime. I personnally completed the game faster because I was getting tired of it towards the end. If you played Just Cause 2 and 3 and still want some more, you can consider this one. If not get Just Cause 3 or even 2. They are better in every aspect.Personnal appreciation : 6/10

Posted: February 11
												An oldie, but a goodie.So picture this: You're a cocky hispanic man tasked with taking down ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• dictators and their governments, so freedom can reign. You do this with openly and with brutal force. Oh, yeah, there's rebels and all that, but they really don't do‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• You're the main guy here. Always remember that. Forget your fashion sense is terrible. Just kill the bad guys, get some kind of girl, and make money while you're at it. That's Just Cause at heart. Fight for freedom because it's a just cause. Blow‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•up just 'cause. The premise (as already mentioned) is interesting. Play as thirty-something Rico, part of an organization that takes down totalitarian governments and defend freedom. I may not have the plot completely down, but's that basically it. The gameplay is very fun. You are given a lot of guns and explosives, and are told where the enemies are, so that you may gun them down like a total badass. There are entire assaults with attacking forces on towns, helicopter dog fights, IFRITs speeding along with guns blazing, and that's just a small part of the game (DISCLAIMER: DO take note that this doesn't happen all the time. The game does take a bit to settle in, and there are some boring parts). You have a lot to do over a sprawling map, with story missions and *many* side quests taking place in lots of locales. Everything looks somewhat picturesque in some cases and detailed. Gunfights aren't boring, but simple. Just general over the shoulder-third person massacres. Driving is the worst part of the game...at least for me. I don't know what it is, but driving is like the one scene in the Polar Express where the train is thrust onto a frozen lake, the cars swinging around like a rope in the breeze. It might be my game, or maybe I need to change something in the settings, but I am unsure.Graphics are nice. The game is old, but not early 2000s old. Meaning that you can run this on a potato and have everything at max settings. I can with my slightly better-than-average craptop. Everything else is pretty good. I can't really find anything wrong with the game.So Just Cause is pretty good. This review certainly doesn't do it much justice, though. Just play it. Then play the sequels that overshadow their older brother. They are all quality games that are very fun. In my opinion, taking into account that the game is old-ish, 10/10.Out of topic: I used to write so eloquently...but now most of my vocabualry is like a vulgar Dr. Pepper: 23 different flavors of the word '‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•'. How charming.
